name: Comb Duck
description: One of the largest ducks. It has a white, dark-spotted head, white neck, chest, and belly. The upper parts are glossy blue-black. Males differ from females by their larger size and a prominent bony knob on the beak.
spread_note: Pantropical distribution – South America (eastern Paraguay, southeastern Brazil, northeastern Argentina), sub-Saharan Africa, Madagascar, and Asia (from Pakistan to southern China)
food_note: Plants and their seeds, aquatic plants, invertebrates
reproduction: Females lay 6–15 eggs, incubated for 28–30 days.
attractions: It most often nests in tree hollows or tall grass. The nest, lined with grass, reeds, and feathers, may sometimes be used by several females at once, resulting in up to 50 eggs. During breeding, the male lives with multiple females, guarding them and the hatched young. Outside the breeding season, comb ducks form flocks of varying sizes.
breeding: We kept them from 1994–2006, and after a break, they’ve been back at the zoo since 2013.
